sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Good morning, Europe. It's Monday, the 31st of January. You've made a right decision to join us here this morning. Let's start by looking at our top stories.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: More pressure on Moscow as US lawmakers say they're preparing the mother of all sanctions against Russia if it launches an attack on Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Portugal's Antonio Costa wins re-election, securing an absolute majority in parliament.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: He vows his top priority will be to turn the page on the pandemic.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: And Rafael Nadal's great comeback.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: The Spanish tennis star recovers from two sets down to win the Australian Open and a record 21st Grand Slam title.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: first Grand Slam title. An emergency session of the UN Security Council is scheduled for today as tension over Ukraine

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: continues to rise.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Diplomatic and financial pressure is being ramped up by the US and European countries on Moscow to deter any sorts of an invasion by its troops amassed on Ukraine's border.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: The US ambassador to the UN, Linda Thomas-Greenfield, has vowed to put Russia on the defensive at the meeting and to press for a clear explanation for the troop build-up.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: While there's been a steady stream of supportive visits by Western politicians to the Ukrainian capital Kiev, Canada's defence minister is the latest.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Russia has denied posing a threat to Ukraine and says it wants mutually respectful relations with the United States.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: TAUT, by bitter experience, we don't want to remain in a position where our security is infringed daily.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: We want good, mutually respectful and equal relations with the United States, as with any other country in the world." Meanwhile, American and European countries are warning that a Russian invasion would trigger heavy sanctions, including actions against Russian banks that could severely undermine the Russian economy. heavy sanctions, including actions against Russian banks that could severely undermine the Russian economy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Antonio Costa has secured a new mandate as Prime Minister of Portugal after a sweeping victory in the country's parliamentary elections.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: His Socialist Party obtained an absolute majority in the 230-seat Portuguese Parliament after securing nearly 42% of the vote.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: With the majority, the Portuguese people confirmed the centrality of the Socialist Party's programme as a programme of government, he said. We have a very clear mission, turn the page of the pandemic and mobilise all our energies to enable our country to progress.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: It was a poor result for Rui Rio's Social Democrats, who had been forecast to perform much more strongly.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: There was an absolutely overwhelming useful vote on the left, he said.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: That is the left mobilised by voting for the Socialist Party to prevent the PSD from being able to nominate the Prime Minister.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: And on the right this did not happen.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: With just the overseas results still to come in,

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: the Socialists have 42% of the vote, well clear of the Social Democratic Party on 29%.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: That translates into 117 deputies in the 230-seat parliament, above the 115-seat threshold needed for an absolute majority.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: The populist Chega party becomes Portugal's third largest with 12 seats.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: For Andre Ventura, the former sports commentator turned leader of the populist Chega party, the result represented mission accomplished.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Chega will be the third political force and will get above 7%, he said.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: The less positive thing is that apparently Antonio Costa will renew a majority to be able to govern.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: I'd say we have some good news and some bad news.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: He promised he would now go after Costa in opposition.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: He promised he would now go after Costa in opposition.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: It was, though, a bad night for the former political allies of the Portuguese Prime Minister, with both the left bloc led by Catarina Martins and the Communist Party of Jer√≥nimo de Souza seeing a big drop in their parliamentary representation.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Their refusal to vote Koshta's budget had helped trigger the election.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Rafael Nadal has won his 21st Grand Slam title,

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: pulling off a scintillating comeback to beat Russia's Daniel Medvedev in the Australian Open. In a match with plenty of twists and turns, it was Medvedev who dashed into an early lead with a strong first set of 2-7. Nadal, however, grew into the occasion in the second set and took a 5-3 lead, but not without Medvedev clawing back into the match to pip Nadal for 6-7.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: The Spanger then stormed through to take the third and fourth set, as Medvedev could not resist any more of the Spaniard's relentless firing.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: For match point, Medvedev could not hold out any longer, after a brief exchange eventually left the Russians struggling to find his footing, allowing Nadal to take the set, the match and the Grand Slam record.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: A Covid test centre in Copenhagen was just one of the casualties of a powerful storm that swept across northern England over the weekend. At least four people were killed as strong gusts of wind brought down trees. Storm Malik advanced across the Nordic region on Sunday bringing with it extensive rain and snowfall.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: In Estonia, rescue workers were called to more than 100 incidents caused by the storm, mostly traffic accidents and cars trapped in the snow.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Rain and sleet are now expected, with the risk of ice on the roads.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: In Poland, rescuers were kept busy dealing with fallen trees, damaged buildings, roofs and electricity lines.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Over 9,000 emergency calls were made to firefighters by people caught out by the ferocity of the conditions.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Meanwhile wind gusts of more than 160km an hour were reported in parts of the Czech Republic, where there was widespread disruption to transport and homes were left without power. There were also strong winds in Scotland, where a woman was killed by a falling tree in Aberdeenshire and in England a nine-year-old boy was also killed after being struck by a tree in Staffordshire.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Thousands of people turned out in Derry City, Northern Ireland to mark the 50th anniversary of Bloody Sunday.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Fourteen innocent Irish Catholics were shot dead by British soldiers on January 30th, 1972.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: The British government apologised in 2010, but no soldiers have been prosecuted by UK courts.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: The families of those that died are still pursuing a campaign to have those responsible brought to justice.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Euronews journalist Ken Murray sent this report from Derry.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Every day since 1972, Kate Nash attends the grave of her brother William. He was one of 14 men shot dead by British soldiers on January 30, 1972. She, like all the other families that suffered, are still demanding that those who carried out the killings are brought to justice.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: I'd like to see the British government give us our third demand, we had three, and that's prosecutions.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: The killings changed Northern Ireland, with hundreds lining up to join the IRA terrorist organisation, prolonging a war that lasted into the late 1990s.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: The Irish government says it is concerned over the treatment of the respective families and says it fully supports their demands.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Right across and respect of all legacy issues that there should be full accountability and that the families and the victims, the families of victims should always have primacy in terms of policy considerations and in terms of dealing with the past.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Thousands of people turned out in Derry on Sunday to remember the 14 that died and to keep up a campaign that aims to bring the British soldiers responsible for the killings to justice.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Local politicians say the British are deliberately engaging in a cover-up.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Well, the British government, of course, covered up what happened on Bloody Sunday for a long time.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Their soldiers were in here murdering unarmed civilians, people who were campaigning for civil rights, marching on their own streets, to have an army coming from a different country, to just shoot them down, to shoot them in the back, shoot them as they were running away, shoot them as they were crawling on the ground.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: You know, nothing can be done to fix that.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: 50 years ago, 14 innocent Irish Catholics were gunned down here by members of the British Army.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: In 2010, the British Prime Minister, David Cameron, issued an apology and accepted that wrong was done.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Despite that, though, nobody has been brought to justice.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: The families of those that died have vowed that despite that apology, the fight will go on.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: This is Ken Murray for Euronews, Derry City, Northern Ireland.
